sen.j: 勅額（ちょくがく）とは、皇帝・天皇などの為政者が国内の寺院に特に与える直筆の書で記された寺額。
sen.e: The tem "imperial scroll" refers to a scroll of temple which was written by statesman such as an emperor and especially given to a temple in the country.
The tem "imperial inscription" ('chokugaku' in Japanese) refers to inscriptions at temples which were written by rulers such as the emperor and typically given to temples throughout the country.

sen.j: 唐朝においては、特定の寺院に勅額を下賜する制度を、国家公認の大寺に対する保護政策として行っていた。
sen.e: The Tang Dynasty had a system to give an imperial scroll to a specific temple as a protective policy for national big temples.
The Tang Dynasty had a system of giving imperial inscriptions to specific temples as a protective policy for large national temples.
The Tang Dynasty had a system of giving imperial inscriptions to specific temples as a protective policy for large national temples.

sen.j: それは、招提や蘭若と称される、非公認の小規模寺院の乱立を予め抑制することが目的であったとされる。
sen.e: It is said that it aimed to prevent the upsurge of nonadmitted small temples which were called shodai and rannya.
It is believed this was to curb the upsurge in unauthorized small temples, which were known as shodai and rannya.

sen.j: その制度の淵源は不明であるが、すでに隋代には行われていたことが知られている。
sen.e: The origin of that system is not clear, but it is known that it was already begun in the Sui Dynasty.
The origin of the system is not clear, but it is known that it was already in place by the Sui Dynasty.

sen.j: 北宋の太宗 (宋)代になると、勅額の下賜は、広範なものへと変質する。
sen.e: In the age of Song Taizong of the Northern Sung Dynasty, imperial scroll became to be given widely to various temples.
During the reign of Emperor Taizong of the Northern Song Dynasty, imperial inscriptions began to be widely granted.
During the reign of Emperor Taizong of the Northern Song Dynasty, imperial inscriptions began to be widely granted.

sen.j: 太平興国3年（978年）、太宗は天下の無額寺院に「太平興国」や「乾明」の寺額を下賜することを発令している。
sen.e: In 978 Song Taizong declared to give a scroll of temple such as 'Taiping Xingguo' and 'Kenmei' to the temples which had no scroll all over the country.
In 978, Emperor Taizong announced the bestowal of inscriptions such as 'Taiping Xingguo' and 'Qian Ming' to temples throughout the country that did not already have inscriptions.
In 978, Emperor Taizong announced the bestowal of inscriptions such as 'Taiping Xingguo' and 'Qian Ming' to temples throughout the country that did not already have inscriptions.

sen.j: その後も、北宋の真宗 (宋)や仁宗 (宋)らの歴代の皇帝が、無額寺院への勅額下賜を度々行っており、司馬光らに諌められている。
sen.e: After that, successive emperors such as Shinso and Jinso of Northern Sung Dynasty sometimes gave an imperial scroll to the temples which had no scroll and they were remonstrated by Guang SIMA and so on.

After that, successive emperors such as the Northern Song Dynasty emperors Zhenzong and Renzong often gave inscriptions to temples that did not already have one, earning warnings from figures such as Guang SIMA.

After that, successive emperors such as the Northern Song Dynasty emperors Zhenzong and Renzong often gave inscriptions to temples that did not already have one, earning warnings from figures such as Guang SIMA.

sen.j: このような勅額下賜の濫発の動機は、修功徳による帝室の安泰祈願であったことが、その詔勅の文言から判明する。
sen.e: It was cleared by the words of Shochoku (imperial edict) that the intention of such excessive grants of imperial scrolls were a prayer of peace of the Imperial family by the practice of pious act (修功徳).
sen.cmt: 「修功徳」の解釈、定訳不明です。文脈から推測しました。
sen.e: This excessive granting of inscriptions was explained in an Imperial edict as being a prayer for the safety of the Imperial family as part of 'cultivating merit and virtue' ('hsiu kung te' in Chinese).

sen.j: それと同時に、勅額寺院の住持を朝廷が任命する「勅差住持制」が行われるようになった。
sen.e: At the same time, 'Chokusa juji system' (勅差住持制) in which a chief priest of the temple with imperial scroll was assigned by the Imperial Court became to be implemented.
sen.cmt: 「勅差住持制」の解釈、定訳不明です。
sen.e: At the same time, the 'Chokusa juji' system, in which the chief priest of temples with an imperial inscription was assigned by the Imperial Court, was implemented.

sen.j: これは、天下の官寺を朝廷主導で序列化し、官寺として国家の手で住持を補任し、皇帝と帝室の安寧を祈祷すると同時に、非課税の恩恵を与える制度である。
sen.e: This is a grading system of kanji (state-sponsored temples) by the Imperial Court in which it assigned a chief priest as kanji and had him pray for the peace of emperor and Imperial family as well as giving a grant of the exclusion from taxation.
